Second validation step: apparent space allocated (differs from actual space used when using sparse files) and compares the apparent available space (total_available * oversub_ratio) to ensure enough space is available for the new volume. :param share: share location :param volume_size_in_gib: int size in GB """ requested_volume_size = volume_size_in_gib * units.Gi total_size, total_available, total_allocated = \ self._get_capacity_info(share) apparent_size = max(0, total_size * self.oversub_ratio) apparent_available = max(0, apparent_size - total_allocated) used = (total_size - total_available) / total_size if used > self.used_ratio: # NOTE(morganfainberg): We check the used_ratio first since # with oversubscription it is possible to not have the actual # available space but be within our oversubscription limit # therefore allowing this share to still be selected as a valid # target. LOG.debug('%s is above used ratio', share) return False if apparent_available <= requested_volume_size: LOG.debug('%s is above oversub ratio', share) return False if total_allocated / total_size >= self.oversub_ratio: LOG.debug('%s reserved space is above oversub ratio', share) return False return True self._set_up_remote_fs_config() nfs_mount_options=self.mount_options) def _get_mount_point_base(self): return 'test' return getattr(self.configuration, 'nfs_mount_point_base', CONF.nfs_mount_point_base) def _get_mount_options(self): return getattr(self.configuration, 'nfs_mount_options', CONF.nfs_mount_options) def _get_oversub_ratio(self): return self.configuration.nfs_oversub_ratio def _get_used_ratio(self): return self.configuration.nfs_used_ratio def _get_shares_config(self): return self.configuration.nfs_shares_config self.shares_config if not self.shares_config: msg = (_("There's no share config file configured (%s)") % if not os.path.exists(self.shares_config): {'config': self.shares_config}) if not self.oversub_ratio > 0: "%s") % self.oversub_ratio if ((not self.used_ratio > 0) and (self.used_ratio <= 1)): "and <= 1.0: %s") % self.used_ratio

For instances with more than one share that meets the criteria, the share with the least "allocated" space will be selected. :param volume_size_in_gib: int size in GB """ if not self._mounted_shares: raise exception.NfsNoSharesMounted() target_share = None target_share_reserved = 0 for nfs_share in self._mounted_shares: if not self._is_share_eligible(nfs_share, volume_size_in_gib): continue total_size, total_available, total_allocated = \ self._get_capacity_info(nfs_share) if target_share is not None: if target_share_reserved > total_allocated: target_share = nfs_share target_share_reserved = total_allocated else: target_share = nfs_share target_share_reserved = total_allocated if target_share is None: raise exception.NfsNoSuitableShareFound( volume_size=volume_size_in_gib) LOG.debug('Selected %s as target nfs share.', target_share) return target_share def _is_share_eligible(self, nfs_share, volume_size_in_gib): """Verifies NFS share is eligible to host volume with given size. First validation step: ratio of actual space (used_space / total_space) is less than 'nfs_used_ratio'. Second validation step: apparent space allocated (differs from actual space used when using sparse files) and compares the apparent available space (total_available * nfs_oversub_ratio) to ensure enough space is available for the new volume. :param nfs_share: nfs share :param volume_size_in_gib: int size in GB """ used_ratio = self.configuration.nfs_used_ratio oversub_ratio = self.configuration.nfs_oversub_ratio requested_volume_size = volume_size_in_gib * units.Gi total_size, total_available, total_allocated = \ self._get_capacity_info(nfs_share) apparent_size = max(0, total_size * oversub_ratio) apparent_available = max(0, apparent_size - total_allocated) used = (total_size - total_available) / total_size if used > used_ratio: # NOTE(morganfainberg): We check the used_ratio first since # with oversubscription it is possible to not have the actual # available space but be within our oversubscription limit # therefore allowing this share to still be selected as a valid # target. LOG.debug('%s is above nfs_used_ratio', nfs_share) return False if apparent_available <= requested_volume_size: LOG.debug('%s is above nfs_oversub_ratio', nfs_share) return False if total_allocated / total_size >= oversub_ratio: LOG.debug('%s reserved space is above nfs_oversub_ratio', nfs_share) return False return True def _get_mount_point_for_share(self, nfs_share): """Needed by parent class.""" return self._remotefsclient.get_mount_point(nfs_share) def _get_capacity_info(self, nfs_share): """Calculate available space on the NFS share. :param nfs_share: example 172.18.194.100:/var/nfs """ mount_point = self._get_mount_point_for_share(nfs_share) df, _ = self._execute('stat', '-f', '-c', '%S %b %a', mount_point, run_as_root=True) block_size, blocks_total, blocks_avail = map(float, df.split()) total_available = block_size * blocks_avail total_size = block_size * blocks_total du, _ = self._execute('du', '-sb', '--apparent-size', '--exclude', '*snapshot*', mount_point, run_as_root=True) total_allocated = float(du.split()[0]) return total_size, total_available, total_allocated def _get_mount_point_base(self): return self.base

commit_message:
Just use int(BOOL) to convert to 1 or 0

(This is split out from I24461f4328e188c8983ad574495e11e033ec5ba4 on
neutron, which was a hunt to remove "PRED and A or B" deprecated ternary
idiom.)

int(bool) already returns only 1 or 0 - no need to do our own explicit
version.

Change-Id: Ib482d6cb63ece7e1d5073fa7dc1c7daf9db8a0b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/85/117385/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make the WBE worker banner information more meaningful

Add in more details that are displayed in the LOG when
a WBE worker is started up that is useful to show to be
able to help in debugging, or other informational and
operational purposes.

Example of the new output is the following:

TaskFlow v0.3.21.62 WBE worker.
Connection details:
  Driver = py-amqp v1.4.5
  Exchange = test
  Topic = test
  Transport = amqp
  Uri = amqp://guest@localhost:5672//
Powered by:
  Executor = concurrent.futures.thread.ThreadPoolExecutor
  Thread count = 3
Supported endpoints:
  - taskflow.tests.utils.NastyTask
  ...
  - taskflow.tests.utils.TaskMultiArgOneReturn
System details:
  Hostname = lappy.gateway.net
  Pid = 28364
  Platform = Linux-3.13.0-30-generic-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-14.04-trusty
  Python = 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56)
  Thread id = 139875992315712

Change-Id: I6d7dba3406007ddc80cce96cfdbbfd25935a12ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/40/109840/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os import platform import socketimport sixfrom taskflow import version self._transport = kwargs.get("transport") self._transport_options = kwargs.get("transport_options", {}) self._exchange = exchange def _generate_banner(self): """Generates a banner that can be useful to display before running.""" lines = [] lines.append("TaskFlow v%s WBE worker." % (version.version_string())) lines.append("Powered by:") lines.append(" Executor = %s" % reflection.get_class_name(self._executor)) if self._threads_count != -1: lines.append(" Thread count = %s" % self._threads_count) lines.append("%s transport:" % self._transport.title()) lines.append(" Exchange = %s" % self._exchange) lines.append(" Topic = %s" % self._topic) lines.append("%s transport options:" % self._transport.title()) for k in sorted(six.iterkeys(self._transport_options)): cleaned_up = k.strip().replace('_', " ").replace("-", " ") cleaned_pieces = cleaned_up.split(" ") pretty_k = cleaned_pieces[0].title() if len(cleaned_pieces) > 1: pretty_k += " " + " ".join(cleaned_pieces[1:]).lower() lines.append(" %s = %s" % (pretty_k, self._transport_options[k])) lines.append("System details:") try: lines.append(" Hostname = %s" % socket.getfqdn()) except socket.error: pass try: lines.append(" Pid = %s" % os.getpid()) except OSError: pass lines.append(" Platform = %s" % platform.platform()) lines.append(" Thread id = %s" % tu.get_ident()) lines.append("Tasks:") for e in self._endpoints: lines.append(" - %s" % e) return lines def run(self): """Runs the worker.""" for line in self._generate_banner(): LOG.info(line)
deleted_lines: def run(self): """Run worker.""" if self._threads_count != -1: LOG.info("Starting the '%s' topic worker in %s threads.", self._topic, self._threads_count) else: LOG.info("Starting the '%s' topic worker using a %s.", self._topic, self._executor) LOG.info("Tasks list:") for e in self._endpoints: LOG.info("|-- %s", e)

subject: Mask passwords in exceptions and error messages
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-26 01:28:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.concurrency/commit/a884bb802082d6ce721338bc67df15e5a9cebd2c', 'message': 'Mask passwords in exceptions and error messages

When a ProcessExecutionError is thrown by processutils.ssh_execute(),
the exception may contain information such as password. Upstream
applications that just log the message (as several appear to do) could
inadvertently expose these passwords to a user with read access to the
log files. It is therefore considered prudent to invoke
strutils.mask_password() on the command, stdout and stderr in the
exception. A test case has been added to ensure that all three are
properly masked.

An earlier commit (e8199714) failed to address ssh_execute(). This
change set addresses ssh_execute.

OSSA is aware of this change request.

Change-Id: I0db9e98cbeb2a5e6f9ae0074f24717aa91cfc238
Closes-Bug: #1343604

commit_message:
Mask passwords in exceptions and error messages

When a ProcessExecutionError is thrown by processutils.ssh_execute(),
the exception may contain information such as password. Upstream
applications that just log the message (as several appear to do) could
inadvertently expose these passwords to a user with read access to the
log files. It is therefore considered prudent to invoke
strutils.mask_password() on the command, stdout and stderr in the
exception. A test case has been added to ensure that all three are
properly masked.

An earlier commit (e8199714) failed to address ssh_execute(). This
change set addresses ssh_execute.

OSSA is aware of this change request.

Change-Id: I0db9e98cbeb2a5e6f9ae0074f24717aa91cfc238
Closes-Bug: #1343604
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.concurrency refs/changes/63/116763/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sanitized_cmd = strutils.mask_password(cmd) LOG.debug('Running cmd (SSH): %s', sanitized_cmd) stdout = strutils.mask_password(stdout_stream.read()) stderr = strutils.mask_password(stderr_stream.read()) cmd=sanitized_cmd)
deleted_lines: LOG.debug('Running cmd (SSH): %s', cmd) stdout = stdout_stream.read() stderr = stderr_stream.read() cmd=cmd)

subject: Fixed restore to work correctly with pexpect
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-16 21:03:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/0817322978eb7899771627aed1e6e2bcb07c626c', 'message': 'Fixed restore to work with newer pexpect

Fixed an issue with restore where it was failing with pexpect 3.2.
pexpect now actually attempts to stop the temp mysqld process (as
opposed to the earlier behavior of only closing file descriptors)
which fails due to a difference in privilege level (since the
process was run with sudo). We now use mysqladmin shutdown to stop
the temp mysqld process.

Change-Id: Iba81648bb1654db97de876dd9a0dbfb04b8811d1

pexpect now actually attempts to stop the temp mysqld process (as
opposed to the earlier behavior of only closing file descriptors)

commit_message:
Fixed restore to work correctly with pexpect

Fixed an issue with restore where it was failing with the latest
version of pexpect in Ubuntu 14.04.

pexpect attempts to stop the temp mysqld process which fails due to
a difference in privilege level (since the process was run with sudo).
We now use mysqladmin shutdown to stop the temp mysqld process.

Closes-Bug: 1343344

Change-Id: Iba81648bb1654db97de876dd9a0dbfb04b8811d1

commit_message:
Refactoring to reduce noise in log files

Currently lot of unnecessary log lines are generated during API
invocation and image transfer. This patch makes log printing
statement changes to reduce noise in log files.

Change-Id: Ifdd43a9d1d32cb6d8957b9805b56729eb9270daf

subject: Cisco VPN with in-band CSR (interim solution)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-14 20:38:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/536b21b1bee5a73dde3acffcc00668e791d0a9f8', 'message': 'Cisco VPN with in-band CSR (interim solution)

Currently, the Cisco VPN drivers use two routers for the proof of concept
solution. A Neutron router provides access to the public and private
subnets, and a Cisco CSR (out-of-band) provides the VPN tunneling.

The end goal is to integrate the Cisco VPN drivers with the Cisco L3
routing plugin being developed (as a separate blueprint), allowing an
in-band CSR to be used as a Neutron router for VPN functionality.

This commit provides an incremental approach to that goal, by modifying
the Cisco VPN drivers to be able to dynamically obtain CSR info from
an INI file, instead of statically reading the INI file at start-up.

A CSR VM can be created out-of-band (or in-band using Nova) and the INI
file can be updated with the router info. Then, the Cisco VPN driver
can use that information (dynamically) to create IPSec connections.

Once the Cisco L3 router plugin is available, the INI file will be
removed, and two calls to the plugin will be used to obtain the needed
router information, for an integrated solution.

The main advantages are:
    - Dynamically use the CSR for VPN.
    - Less manual intervention and setup.
    - Easy migration to final solution.
    - No dependency on the Cisco L3 router plugin implementation.

Note 1: The INI unit tests are moved from device driver to service
        driver and modified.

Note 2: I added a unit test for deleting IPSec site-to-site connection,
        which was missing (pass).

Note 3: For more details on the change, you can view this Google Doc:
        http://goo.gl/DXir8c

Change-Id: I307fc79952e3e12a0f77679ac1fc2b314fa63684

commit_message:
Cisco VPN with in-band CSR (interim solution)

Currently, the Cisco VPN drivers use two routers for the proof of concept
solution. A Neutron router provides access to the public and private
subnets, and a Cisco CSR (out-of-band) provides the VPN tunneling.

The end goal is to integrate the Cisco VPN drivers with the Cisco L3
routing plugin being developed (as a separate blueprint), allowing an
in-band CSR to be used as a Neutron router for VPN functionality.

This commit provides an incremental approach to that goal, by modifying
the Cisco VPN drivers to be able to dynamically obtain CSR info from
an INI file, instead of statically reading the INI file at start-up.

A CSR VM can be created out-of-band (or in-band using Nova) and the INI
file can be updated with the router info. Then, the Cisco VPN driver
can use that information (dynamically) to create IPSec connections.

Once the Cisco L3 router plugin is available, the INI file will be
removed, and two calls to the plugin will be used to obtain the needed
router information, for an integrated solution.

The main advantages are:
    - Dynamically use the CSR for VPN.
    - Less manual intervention and setup.
    - Easy migration to final solution.
    - No dependency on the Cisco L3 router plugin implementation.

Note 1: The INI unit tests are moved from device driver to service
        driver and modified.

Note 2: I added a unit test for deleting IPSec site-to-site connection,
        which was missing (pass).

Note 3: For more details on the change, you can view this Google Doc:
        http://goo.gl/DXir8c

Change-Id: I307fc79952e3e12a0f77679ac1fc2b314fa63684
Partially-Implements: blueprint cisco-vpnaas-with-cisco-csr-router

Provide a description for syntax error

Before this change, 'None' was reported without additional information
Now the reason of error and expression, where it's occurred reported successfully

Partly-Closes-Bug: #1342403

Limiting requests <2.4.0

from urllib3 which is not handled. Limiting version under 2.4.0.

Change-Id: I795db0f31a85179e17db44f097f1732a1436972c

commit_message:
Explicitly set DIB_REPOREF_*

Explicitly tell source-repositories which revision of a project to pull
in, source-repositories by default pulls in "master", which is ok for
all projects except the one we actually want to test (devstack-gate
leaves the commit we want checked out in a detached head).

Upto now we haven't been testing the correct version of most of the
commits in the experimental queue.

Change-Id: Ibb4be09b22179d62c9d6f0afb2525c521bb3f36d
Closes-Bug: #1364345

commit_message:
Sahara clusters networking parameters

Added support for floating_ip_pool and neutron_management_network
parameters. These parameters will allow to becnchmark Sahara in all
network configurations.

Change-Id: I17c601695a38ed01c6e932b3c18fefe6bee703c7

Enable H202, H402, H404 rules

* H202 assertRaises Exception too broad
* H402 one line docstring needs punctuation
* H404 multi line docstring should start without a leading new line

commit_message:
Adds network creation instructions

Set of instructions for configuring Neutron with flat networking inorder to enable Ironic to connect to the Baremetal server

Change-Id: Iff8b42ce414fd0e7bb09eb7a9809ba8d32264296
Partial-Bug: 1323589
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/86/114886/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Configuring Neutron to talk with the Baremetal: ============================================== With Flat networking: 1. Edit /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini and modify these: [ml2] type_drivers = flat tenant_network_types = flat mechanism_drivers = openvswitch [ml2_type_flat] flat_networks = physnet1 [securitygroup] firewall_driver = neutron.agent.linux.iptables_firewall.OVSHybridIptablesFirewallDriver enable_security_group = True [ovs] network_vlan_ranges = physnet1 bridge_mappings = physnet1:br-eth2 # Replace eth2 with the interface you are using to connect to the baremetal server. 2. Add the integration bridge to Open vSwitch: ovs-vsctl add-br br-int 3. Create the br-eth2 network bridge to handle communication between the openstack setup and the baremetal node using eth2: ovs-vsctl add-br br-eth2 ovs-vsctl add-port br-eth2 eth2 4. Restart the Open vSwitch agent: service neutron-plugin-openvswitch-agent restart # On restarting the neutron open vSwitch agent, the veth pair between the bridges br-int and br-eth2 is automatically created. # Your open vSwitch bridges should look something like this after following the above steps: ovs-vsctl show Bridge br-ex Port "eth1" Interface "eth1" Port br-ex Interface br-ex type: internal Bridge br-int Port "int-br-eth2" Interface "int-br-eth2" Port br-int Interface br-int type: internal Bridge "br-eth2" Port "br-eth2" Interface "br-eth2" type: internal Port "phy-br-eth2" Interface "phy-br-eth2" Port "eth2" Interface "eth2" ovs_version: "2.0.1" 5. Create the flat network on which you are going to launch the instance: neutron net-create --tenant-id $TENANT_ID sharednet1 --shared --provider:network_type flat \ --provider:physical_network physnet1

commit_message:
Make log level in linux.utils.execute configurable

Function linux.utils.execute always logs failures on error level.
Some callers use this function to check resource existance and
interpret failure as normal flow. Log level is made configurable
for such cases.

Change-Id: I8e4cd7b42234426f8fe58d353a64e898f02f8998
Closes-bug: 1339045

commit_message:
Extend software_configs API for SoftwareComponent

This patch extends the software_configs API backend to support multiple
'configs' in one resource, as it is the case for the new
OS::Heat::SoftwareComponent resource type that is derived from
OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig.

Change-Id: Ie16d281aed364e45456296d95606037d54df9651
Implements: partial-blueprint action-aware-sw-config

Defer "Storm Integration" to Kilo

time for implementing it. Due to the nature of the feature (new plugin
addition), there is no need to re-review spec for Kilo.

time for implementing it. Due to the nature of the feature (new plugin
addition), there is no need to re-review spec for Kilo.

Change-Id: I814d1d8696f23aef38774e62ac5c2a43a5a727a7

commit_message:
Remove localboot provides.

The current element-provides points to localboot
which results in error. Removing it to make it work
as its not needed at all.

Change-Id: I506fbf460fad46aa9b9ba6dd82fb7524894bbbe7

commit_message:
Add send-data-to-ceilometer support for pxe_ipminative driver

This patch will implement pxe_ipminative driver *get_sensors_data* method to get
sensor data by pyghmi get_sensor_data() method call.

Spec:
https://github.com/openstack/ironic-specs/blob/master/specs/juno/send-data-to-ceilometer.rst

Related patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/72538/

Change-Id: I2368e78e39970b7a3cffe3d8cb2dd3fce5056635
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/86/112486/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _normalize_sensors_data(node, data): sensors_data = {} if data: for reading in data: if not reading.value: continue if reading.type not in sensors_data: sensors_data[reading.type] = {} sensors_data[reading.type][reading.name] = { 'Sensor Reading': reading.value, 'Sensor ID': reading.name, 'States': reading.states, 'Units': reading.units, 'Health': reading.health} return sensors_data :raises: FailedToGetSensorData when getting the sensor data fails. :raises: FailedToParseSensorData when parsing sensor data fails. :raises: InvalidParameterValue if required ipmi parameters are missing :returns: returns a dict of sensor data group by sensor type. driver_info = _parse_driver_info(task.node) try: ipmicmd = ipmi_command.Command(bmc=driver_info['address'], userid=driver_info['username'], password=driver_info['password']) ret = ipmicmd.get_sensor_data() except pyghmi_exception.IpmiException as e: LOG.error(_LE("IPMI get sensor data failed for node %(node_id)s " "with the following error: %(error)s"), {'node_id': driver_info['uuid'], 'error': e}) raise exception.FailedToGetSensorData(cmd=e) return _normalize_sensors_data(task.node, ret)
deleted_lines: Not implemented by this driver. raise NotImplementedError()

commit_message:
Set no-quorum-policy using cibadmin patch

Pacemaker crmsh utility may sometimes fail
when trying to set no-quorum policy as
xml-diff becomes outdated.

This approach uses cibadmin patch option
that applies xml diff cleanly.

Change-Id: I63297d33ab20c7dd48ffa5064a981d6555c6b502
Closes-bug: #1363908
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/64/118164/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: xml = <<-EOF <diff> <diff-removed> <cib> <configuration> <crm_config> <cluster_property_set id="cib-bootstrap-options"> <nvpair value="ignore" id="cib-bootstrap-options-no-quorum-policy"/> </cluster_property_set> </crm_config> </configuration> </cib> </diff-removed> <diff-added> <cib> <configuration> <crm_config> <cluster_property_set id="cib-bootstrap-options"> <nvpair value="stop" id="cib-bootstrap-options-no-quorum-policy"/> </cluster_property_set> </crm_config> </configuration> </cib> </diff-added> </diff> EOF cmd = "/usr/sbin/cibadmin --patch --sync-call --xml-text #{xml}"

commit_message:
Replaced keystoneclient with keystonemiddleware

keystoneclient.middleware is depricated now. Replaced it with
keystonemiddleware.

Change-Id: I941d25e534411497767b22b03d37d3f9c4de04a1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnetodb refs/changes/85/118385/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: paste.filter_factory = keystonemiddleware.auth_token:filter_factory

commit_message:
Use __qualname__ where appropriate

The __qualname__ attribute simplifies the determination
of an objects class name and callable name and is useful
in python 3.x to be able to use since it can correctly
identify names better than the python 2.x __name__ attribute
can.

Adds a few tests in to ensure that the usage of __qualname__
where available functions as expected.

See: http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3155/

Fixes bug 1341441

Change-Id: Ic6942cbbc8e35d65fb3ac603ff1dfc8e20c194a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/83/106683/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: return '.'.join((obj.__module__, obj.__qualname__)) except AttributeError: return '.'.join((obj.__module__, obj.__name__)) # This is a bound method. if isinstance(method_self, six.class_types): # This is a bound class method. try: parts = (im_class.__module__, function.__qualname__) except AttributeError: parts = (im_class.__module__, im_class.__name__, function.__name__) elif inspect.isfunction(function) or inspect.ismethod(function): # TODO(harlowja): this is not completely right for static methods # which vary in naming between python 2.x and python 3.x (in python # 3.x static methods have a '__qualname__' which includes the class, # this is not the case in python 2.x where '__name__' is just the # function name). try: parts = (im_class.__module__, im_class.__qualname__) except AttributeError: parts = (im_class.__module__, im_class.__name__)
deleted_lines: return '.'.join((obj.__module__, obj.__name__)) # this is bound method if isinstance(method_self, six.class_types): # this is bound class method parts = (im_class.__module__, im_class.__name__, function.__name__) elif inspect.isfunction(function) or inspect.ismethod(function): parts = (im_class.__module__, im_class.__name__)

'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2014-07-23 18:14:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/cebc25dbe8a9c3b2dfa6fde9ca562321dd55f767', 'message': 'Add a check_telemetry method to javelin

Adds simple queries of the telemetry service to allow checks that meter
data effectively survives an upgrade. The checks make the perhaps
not robust assumption that there will be at least two samples (per
query) and that the first one comes from before the upgrade and the
last one comes from after the upgrade.

This can be made more robust with some awareness of time. That is:
If we know that the upgrade process will last at least N seconds
we can look for that gap in the samples to confirm that earlier
samples are substantially older than the current time or the
time on the more recent samples.

Question:
* How do we get awareness of time?

Partially implements: blueprint grenade-resource-survivability

Change-Id: Ie759d71326916d543c7b3603d8812306d093715a
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2014-07-28 09:53:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/35437e54cedaff756c882d800e29739840e9d627', 'message': 'Add a check_telemetry method to javelin

Adds simple queries of the telemetry service to allow checks that meter
data effectively survives an upgrade. At this time the tests
check the first and last samples in the database. This could be the
same sample.

Getting robust tests is challenging because check mode is run both
before and after the upgrade with the same tests.

Partially implements: blueprint grenade-resource-survivability

Change-Id: Ie759d71326916d543c7b3603d8812306d093715a
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-08-06 17:29:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/947da45a478df428f090f1a197a9776686959f9c', 'message': 'Add a check_telemetry method to javelin

Adds simple queries of the telemetry service that check that meter
data properly survives an upgrade. The code is written so it is
possible to make different queries before and after the upgrade.

resources.yaml is changed so that the generated servers have
different owners and images.

Partially implements: blueprint grenade-resource-survivability

Change-Id: Ie759d71326916d543c7b3603d8812306d093715a
'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2014-08-08 14:39:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/a339bb4d33a65b5a87e974c28673156a174f42ab', 'message': 'Add a check_telemetry method to javelin

Adds simple queries of the telemetry service that check that meter
data properly survives an upgrade. The code is written so it is
possible to make different queries before and after the upgrade.

UPGRADE_GAP provides a timedelta against which it should be
possible to declare that a sample comes before or after
JAVELIN_START (the time at which the javelin command was
called). This is done in an effort to avoid ambiguity of
sample data and race conditions with notifications made
by nova and polling done by the ceilometer compute agent.

resources.yaml is changed so that the generated servers have
different owners and images.

Partially implements: blueprint grenade-resource-survivability

Change-Id: Ie759d71326916d543c7b3603d8812306d093715a

possible to make different queries before and after the upgrade.

UPGRADE_GAP provides a timedelta against which it should be
possible to declare that a sample comes before or after
JAVELIN_START (the time at which the javelin command was
called). This is done in an effort to avoid ambiguity of
sample data and race conditions with notifications made
by nova and polling done by the ceilometer compute agent.
This is not yet perfect: a better solution would involve
knowing the timestamp on the data-dumpfile made during
the upgrade process and using that a selector for timestamps.
We can only use JAVELIN_START to ensure that old samples are
in fact old. It does not work for new samples as the ceilometer
compute agent can produce samples at three distinct times:

* in the previous run (before the upgrade)
* in the new run before JAVELIN_START
* in the new run after JAVELIN_START (it takes a while for the
  agent to get rolling).

The latter possibility is covered by a loop which waits up to sixty
seconds for sensible polling data during check mode.

resources.yaml is changed so that the generated servers have
different owners and images as available factors to sample.

Partially implements: blueprint grenade-resource-survivability

Change-Id: Ie759d71326916d543c7b3603d8812306d093715a

'}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2014-08-18 16:03:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/bedd6fe3b90391dc3cf39068f6599ee387cc9653', 'message': 'Add a check_telemetry method to javelin

Adds simple queries of the telemetry service that check that meter
data properly survives an upgrade. The code is written so it is
possible to make different queries before and after the upgrade.

UPGRADE_GAP provides a timedelta against which it should be
possible to declare that a sample comes before or after
JAVELIN_START (the time at which the javelin command was
called). This is done in an effort to avoid ambiguity of
sample data and race conditions with notifications made
by nova and polling done by the ceilometer compute agent.
Since we can only use JAVELIN_START to ensure that old samples
are in fact old we also inspect the modified time on the ceilometer
data dump file and use that to compare new samples against it.

With these comparisons we can know that we have samples from before
and after the upgrade, still in the database.

Compute agent can produce samples at three distinct times:

* in the previous run (before the upgrade)
* in the new run before JAVELIN_START
* in the new run after JAVELIN_START (it takes a while for the
  agent to get rolling).

N.B: This currently cannot work and is expected to fail because
it relies on accessing information which grenade does not yet
provide to it.

Partially implements: blueprint grenade-resource-survivability

Change-Id: Ie759d71326916d543c7b3603d8812306d093715a

commit_message:
Add a check_telemetry method to javelin

Adds simple queries of the telemetry service that check that meter
data properly survives an upgrade.

JAVELIN_START is recorded to provide a way to confirm that the
oldest available data is from before the upgrade, thus confirming
that the data survived the upgrade.

Partially implements: blueprint grenade-resource-survivability

Change-Id: Ie759d71326916d543c7b3603d8812306d093715a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/54/102354/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest.services.telemetry.json import telemetry_client# NOTE(chdent): I had to set BASENAME (and use it) to get a working run # while experimenting to develop this test. I ran as: # # python tempest/cmd/javelin.py -m create -r tempest/cmd/resources.yaml # python tempest/cmd/javelin.py -m check -r tempest/cmd/resources.yaml # # Without BASENAME set (in some fashion) images are not loaded # into glance and instances are not created. This leads to failures # in check mode but not actual error message as exceptions are being # swallowed by sys.excepthook getting set in tempest.common.log:setup(). # Presumably that is useful for some contexts but is extremely # unfriendly to wandering curious devs who want to learn by breaking # stuff (or I've missed some piece of the piece and I'm confused # (very likely)). # # I would guess that setting this via the resources.yaml file or # using full paths where files are called is the right thing to do. # I'm not sure what will happen in the gate, obviously there's no # /home/cdent there, so commented... BASENAME = '/home/cdent/src/devstack/files/images/cirros-0.3.2-x86_64-uec' self.telemetry = telemetry_client.TelemetryClientJSON(_auth) self.check_telemetry() def check_telemetry(self): """Check that ceilometer returns a sane statistic. We check to see if there are the number of virtual cpus in use for the instances that were created in the create phase. """ # NOTE(chdent): This is a pretty lame check for sanity. All # we're really doing is making sure that the API is still up # and the data survived the upgrade. That's nice to know but # I suspect we can do better. for user in self.users: user_id = USERS[user]['id'] vcpu_count = len([server for server in self.res['servers'] if server['owner'] == user]) client = client_for_user(user) stats_query = ('user_id', 'eq', '%s' % user_id) r, body = client.telemetry.list_statistics( 'vcpus', query=stats_query) if body: self.assertEqual(body[0]['max'], vcpu_count) with open(os.path.join(BASENAME, image['aki']), 'r') as f: r, body = client.images.store_image(aki.get('id'), f) with open(os.path.join(BASENAME, image['ari']), 'r') as f: client.images.store_image(ari.get('id'), f) with open(os.path.join(BASENAME, image['file']), 'r') as f: r. body = client.images.store_image(image_id, f)
deleted_lines: client.images.store_image(aki.get('id'), open(image['aki'], 'r')) client.images.store_image(ari.get('id'), open(image['ari'], 'r')) client.images.store_image(image_id, open(image['file'], 'r'))

commit_message:
Migrate test_network_basic_ops to tempest clients

This patch migrates the network basic ops scenario tests
from official client to tempest clients.

manager:
Creates NeutronScenario subclass to enforce usage of neutron instead of nova
network. Overrides novanetwork helper methods from ancestor (such as secgroup
related methods). Class name is temporary since NetworkScenario is used by
non-migrated scenario. Will be changed to NetworkScenario once all network
tests have migrated

resources:
Creates DeletableResource module in services/network for resources using
the tempest clients. Copy of api/network/common. Original will be removed once
all related scenarios have migrated.
Changes __hash__ to use object's uuid instead of memory address.

network_basic_ops:
Changes references to server object to handle dict and scenarios keypair dict
to use key_name as keys instead of servers (since server is an unhashable dict)

Partially-implements: bp:tempest-client-scenarios

Change-Id: Id7341c662c0faad3ab0cb3fc1579326613ac9c68

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-08 20:33:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/31eab2cb6b5cc1f7256b3c92722414dfd0b99a64', 'message': 'WIP to rationalize SQL in alignment with new schema

This is just some exploration to see how much needs to change
to get simpler queries when using the new schema proposed
in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/111313/11

The primary insight here is that the scenario tests create
samples which are considered impossible in the "real" world.
Changing the tests (as done) allows more straightforward
queries of the resource and meter tables (and potentially
more, thus the WIP).

The mongo storage implementation works with _either_ these tests or
the unchanged tests because it only saves the most recent resource
representation anyway.

At the moment the only code-side change is get_meters of the sql-a
implementation. In that a subquery (present to duplicate the mongo
behavior) is removed and the sample table is joined. This leads to
a much simpler query plan with 3 tables instead of 5 or 6 tables,
duplicate tables or temporary tables involved. This ought to result
in much better reads when doing a meter-list, even when joining
the metadata tables.

NB: I have not yet performance tested these changes, only explored
the query plan. It is possible (but unlikely) that simple selects
using indexes will be slower than more complex queries, so we should
be sure to do real tests. The current query arrangement is one of
several options. In situations with more data one of those other
options may be better.

Nest steps (if any):

* try with lots of data, explore other options
* explore the other usual queries to see what additional simplifications
  are possible (if any)

Change-Id: I28db654fbfe5aa9809e3024770cf7182bcecc58e

commit_message:
WIP to rationalize SQL in alignment with new schema

This is just some exploration to see how much needs to change
to get simpler queries when using the new schema proposed
in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/111313/11

The primary insight here is that the scenario tests create
samples which are considered impossible in the "real" world.
Changing the tests (as done) allows more straightforward
queries of the resource and meter tables (and potentially
more, thus the WIP).

The mongo storage implementation works with _either_ these tests or
the unchanged tests because it only saves the most recent resource
representation anyway.

At the moment the only code-side change is get_meters of the sql-a
implementation. In that a subquery (present to duplicate the mongo
behavior) is removed and the sample table is joined. This leads to
a much simpler query plan with 3 tables instead of 5 or 6 tables,
duplicate tables or temporary tables involved. This ought to result
in much better reads when doing a meter-list, even when joining
the metadata tables.

Note that postgresql requires either many group by statements, or
a distinct(). mysql and sqlite do not.

NB: I have not yet performance tested these changes, only explored
the query plan. It is possible (but unlikely) that simple selects
using indexes will be slower than more complex queries, so we should
be sure to do real tests. The current query arrangement is one of
several options. In situations with more data one of those other
options may be better.

Next steps (if any):

* try with lots of data, explore other options
* explore event handling (other get_* methods already explored)

Change-Id: I28db654fbfe5aa9809e3024770cf7182bcecc58e

commit_message:
Persist sahara configuration in cluster object

Change-Id: I5001dfda5527439cf7a479e25a6f0006882ddfab
Blueprint: cluster-persist-sahara-configuration
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-specs refs/changes/11/117011/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Store Sahara configuration in cluster properties ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/sahara/+spec/cluster-persist-sahara-configuration It is important to know Sahara version and configuration for proper cluster migration and preventing dangerous operations. Problem description =================== Now Sahara has no way to know conditions when cluster was created. Cluster operations after Openstack upgrade or switching infrastructure engine could be dangerous and cause data loss. Proposed change =============== Store main Sahara properties (version, infrastructure engine, etc) to cluster DB object. This will allow to prevent dangerous operations and notify user gracefully. Alternatives ------------ Don't store any information about Sahara settings. Always assume that settings didn't change and we have current or previous release of OpenStack. Data model impact ----------------- New field in cluster object. Probably this should be dictionary with defined keys. REST API impact --------------- We can expose information about Sahara settings to user. Or not. Other end user impact --------------------- Some error messages could become more descriptive. Deployer impact --------------- None Developer impact ---------------- More options to handle errors. Sahara-image-elements impact ---------------------------- None Sahara-dashboard / Horizon impact --------------------------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: alazarev Work Items ---------- Implement change Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Manual Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Convert migrate_server v3 plugin to v2.1

Changes required to have v3 plugin natively support
the v2 API.

The migrate_live action is reverted back to os-migrateLive

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: Ib3332ecfbf47ed6cad6108399083f0c26b7eebfe

commit_message:
Call policy.init() once per API request

This patch changes the policy engine behaviour and the API base
controller in order to ensure policy.init is invoked only once
for each API request.
This will avoid issues arising from policy file updates during
API processing and speed up response generation for list operations,
by about 5%.

This patch also removes an obsolete TODO comment.

Change-Id: I108ebd26fccdea19cb00959f70d87c3bc1587df9
Closes-Bug: 1302611

commit_message:
console: add typed console objects

Adds typed console objects used by virt driver API to
return information about consoles.

Also updates virt drivers to use them.

Closes-Bug: #1361611
Change-Id: I8f6a857b88659ee30b4aa1a25ac52d7e01156a68

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections class Console(collections.MutableMapping): def __init__(self, host, port, internal_access_path=None): self.host = host self.port = port self.internal_access_path = internal_access_path def __getitem__(self, key): return self.__dict__[key] def __setitem__(self, key, value): self.__dict__[key] = value def __delitem__(self, key): del self.__dict__[key] def __iter__(self): return iter(self.__dict__) def __len__(self): return len(self.__dict__) class ConsoleVNC(Console): pass class ConsoleSpice(Console): def __init__(self, host, port, tlsPort, internal_access_path=None): super(ConsoleSpice, self).__init__(host, port, internal_access_path) self.tlsPort = tlsPort

commit_message:
Transfer class LazyPluggable from nova to oslo.utils

Need to transfer code of class LazyPluggable to oslo.utils
because this code copied in different projects. Global
attribute CONF is now transmitted in __init__ function.
Also was written tests for this class.

Change-Id: I1c828b643408d9a458f2facdf7e07b4ca7dfb64a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/71/118571/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo.config import cfg def test_load_lazy_pluggable_without_config_group(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' from_list = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=module_name) self.assertIs(__import__(module_name, None, None, from_list), _backend._get_backend()) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_with_config_group(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') test_group = cfg.OptGroup(name='group', title='Test Options') conf.register_group(test_group) conf.register_opt(test_backend, test_group) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' from_list = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group='group', bar=module_name) self.assertIs(__import__(module_name, None, None, from_list), _backend._get_backend()) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_when_backend_is_tuple(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' from_list = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=(module_name, from_list)) self.assertIs(__import__(module_name, None, None, from_list), _backend._get_backend()) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_when_backend_tuple_length_is_incorrect(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=tuple(module_name)) self.assertRaises(ValueError, _backend._get_backend) def test_load_lazy_pluggable_raise_of_PluginLoadError(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar_1', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar_2=module_name) self.assertRaises(importutils.PluginLoadError, _backend._get_backend) def test_verify_lazyness_itself(self): conf = cfg.ConfigOpts() test_backend = cfg.StrOpt('foo', default='bar', help='This module will be imported lazily') conf.register_opt(test_backend) module_name = 'tests.test_importutils' _backend = importutils.LazyPluggable(conf, 'foo', config_group=None, bar=module_name) self.assertIsNone(_backend._backend)

commit_message:
Keystone/LDAP integration

Installs python-ldap and ldappool modules into Keystone virtual environment.

Configuration settings related to LDAP are supposed to be set via
passthrough feature (i.e. injected into /etc/keystone/keystone.conf file
by setting "keystone" field of $OVERCLOUD_EXTRA_CONFIG env variable).

Change-Id: Ifcd403cff3a75a9926d2a4ee7d041ef9f3171ffb

commit_message:
Make m-shr more stable on start up

When service m-shr is restarted it tries to ensure shares and its rules.
If some error appears whole service fails to start up.
Lets catch all exceptions, log them and let service start anyway.

Closes-Bug: #1351195
Change-Id: I979932b5a80ff2e1494c361887a1c1dea63daeb5

subject: Fix scheduled share creation with generic driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-29 11:52:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/4dfde513de9e05ae43ffcfcc60d48a0cd9eb2f10', 'message': 'Fix scheduled share creation with generic driver

Generic driver uses separate module service_instance for handling of Nova VMs.
If service m-shr starts and there are exist scheduled shares for creation,
then appears concurrent issue between method 'do_setup', that is called once
on start of service and 'ensure_server', that uses stuff from do_setup.

Main error is following:
- "Returning exception 'GenericShareDriver' object has no attribute
  'service_instance_manager' to caller"

Changes:
- moved definition of attr 'service_instance_manager' to __init__ method.
- removed attrs '_helpers' and 'share_networks_servers' for
  ServiceInstanceManager as redundant.
- updated unittests according to changes.

Change-Id: I0fe7f097dc03eade5e0d4dfdbda0eb49588f4dde
Closes-Bug: #1362985
Related-Bug: #1330391

commit_message:
Fix scheduled share creation with generic driver

Generic driver uses separate module service_instance for handling of Nova VMs.
If service m-shr starts and there are existing scheduled shares for creation,
then concurrent issue appears between method 'do_setup', that is called once
on start of service and 'ensure_server', that uses stuff from do_setup.

Main error is in following:
- "Returning exception 'GenericShareDriver' object has no attribute
  'service_instance_manager' to caller"

Changes:
- moved definition of attr 'service_instance_manager' to __init__ method.
- removed attrs '_helpers' and 'share_networks_servers' from
  ServiceInstanceManager as they are redundant.
- updated unittests according to changes.
- used direct import of 'constants' submodule for neutron api,
  to be able to access it on driver init step.
- replaced generic driver with common driver interface for inheritance
  by fake driver for unittests.

Change-Id: I0fe7f097dc03eade5e0d4dfdbda0eb49588f4dde
Closes-Bug: #1362985
Related-Bug: #1330391
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/61/117761/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.service_instance_manager = ( service_instance.ServiceInstanceManager( self.db, driver_config=self.configuration))
deleted_lines: self.service_instance_manager = service_instance.\ ServiceInstanceManager(self.db, self._helpers, driver_config=self.configuration) self.share_networks_servers = ( self.service_instance_manager.share_networks_servers)

commit_message:
Use oslo.serialization

Use jsonutils from lib oslo.serialization instead of
common code.
Module jsonutils from common code in nova can't be removed right
now due to the usage in other common modules. This should
be done after switching oslo code to use serialization library.

Also added hacking check for using jsonutils from oslo.serialization
library

Change-Id: I0d97f9faff081b572075a3b7aca042f9aeb948ae

commit_message:
Configure keepalived vip based on bootstrap node value

With this patch becomes possible seamlessly use keepalived configuration
for each controllerConfig

Change-Id: Ib3a21e65926251de53bb1881345f81e12213723b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/69/93769/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eu TEMPLATE_ROOT=$(os-apply-config --print-templates) if os-is-bootstrap-host; then install -m 0644 -o root -g root $(dirname $0)/../files/vip-master.conf $TEMPLATE_ROOT/etc/keepalived/conf.d/vip-master.conf else install -m 0644 -o root -g root $(dirname $0)/../files/vip-backup.conf $TEMPLATE_ROOT/etc/keepalived/conf.d/vip-backup.conf fi

commit_message:
On ubuntu break app logs into their own files

Currently on ubuntu we are sending all app logs to syslog which munges
them all together into /var/log/syslog. This makes debugging a somewhat
painful experience.

Change-Id: I89f9ddc168f08b90cece7cf5af2e032b2c4f5371
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/64/118464/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Log each app to its own log file $template tripleoAppLogFile,"/var/log/%programname%.log" user.notice ?tripleoAppLogFile

commit_message:
Initial translation setup

To start translation, we need to initially import the
translation file - and place it at the proper place so that
the usual CI scripts can handle it.

The proper place is for all python projects
$PROJECT/locale/$PROJECT.pot - see setup.cfg.

Further imports of the pot files and its translations
will be done by the OpenStack Proposal bot in a daily job.

Change-Id: Ic39a4cfe40ccdff4d6a299189fcfc0e6a9ec9c61

subject: Switch partitioned alarm evaluation to a hash-based approach
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-19 10:33:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/48a8265f84dc05f9adc96955e3145e18484d5f41', 'message': 'Switch partitioned alarm evaluation to a hash-based approach

Short version: make use of the new distributed workload partitioning
utilities in Ceilometer to simplify the alarm evaluation
partitioning.

Longer version:
The assignment of alarms to individual partitioned alarm evaluators
now follows the same pattern as the division of resources between
scaled-out central agents.

The evaluators each join a tooz group and emit a periodic heartbeat
to tooz. Tooz provides distributed group membership information.

Thus the set of evaluators share minimal knowledge, but this is
sufficient to guide a hash-based approach to determining whether
an individual alarm UUID falls under the responsibility of an
individual evaluator.

The current RPC-fanout-based presence reporting and the master/slave
division of responsibilities can be dropped. Also the rebalancing
logic when a certain threshold of alarm deletion is crossed is no
longer be required.

Change-Id: Ica8dae569f9ff1c2f8fe58be6ae2def66be0da54
Implements: blueprint hash-based-alarm-partitioning
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-08-21 08:17:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/73145924aa4814a915894e86611c4f55d40b2b9c', 'message': 'Switch partitioned alarm evaluation to a hash-based approach

commit_message:
Switch partitioned alarm evaluation to a hash-based approach

Short version: make use of the new distributed workload partitioning
utilities in Ceilometer to simplify the alarm evaluation
partitioning. Code is intentionally non-consolidated to enable
easy deletion of 'singleton' and 'partitioned' services in the Kilo
cycle.

Longer version:
The assignment of alarms to individual partitioned alarm evaluators
now follows the same pattern as the division of resources between
scaled-out central agents.

The evaluators each join a tooz group and emit a periodic heartbeat
to tooz. Tooz provides distributed group membership information.

Thus the set of evaluators share minimal knowledge, but this is
sufficient to guide a hash-based approach to determining whether
an individual alarm UUID falls under the responsibility of an
individual evaluator.

The current RPC-fanout-based presence reporting and the master/slave
division of responsibilities can be dropped in the next cycle.
Also the rebalancing logic when a certain threshold of alarm
deletion is crossed will no longer be required.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ica8dae569f9ff1c2f8fe58be6ae2def66be0da54
Implements: blueprint hash-based-alarm-partitioning

""" import contextlib import mock from stevedore import extension from ceilometer.alarm import service from ceilometer.openstack.common.fixture import config from ceilometer.tests import base as tests_base class TestPartitionedAlarmService(tests_base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestPartitionedAlarmService, self).setUp() self.threshold_eval = mock.Mock() self.api_client = mock.MagicMock() self.CONF = self.useFixture(config.Config()).conf self.CONF.set_override('host', 'fake_host') self.CONF.set_override('partition_rpc_topic', 'fake_topic', group='alarm') self.setup_messaging(self.CONF) self.partitioned = service.PartitionedAlarmService() self.partitioned.tg = mock.Mock() self.partitioned.partition_coordinator = mock.Mock() self.extension_mgr = commit_message:
Bump boto to 2.32.1

This version seems compatible with Python 3.x; making sure it is used will make
porting Nova and Glance easier.

Fix execution state ERROR if task_spec has on-finish

 * We shouldn't set execution state in ERROR if
   task has on-error or on-finish property
 * Fix wait_success method in functional tests

commit_message:
First patch and first review docs

These docs contain information on how to make the first
contributions to Zaqar and how to make the first review
in Gerrit for Zaqar to the developer's manual.

Change-Id: I291ad85d735a3a096a36afa7650a08a37dbb4e89
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/69/115369/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Your first patch ================ This section describes how to create your first patch and upload it to Gerrit_ to be reviewed. Set up your contributor accounts ------------------------------- You will need to create a Launchpad_ account. You will be able to login into the Gerrit_ review system with your launchpad account. Before we can accept your patches, you'll will also have to sign the `Contributors License Agreement`_. Lastly, you are going to need to `upload an SSH key`_ to Gerrit to be able to commit changes for review. Visit the the `Gerrit Workflow's account setup`_ section in the wiki to get more information on setting up your accounts. .. _Launchpad: http://launchpad.net/ .. _Gerrit: http://review.openstack.org/ .. _`Contributors License Agreement`_: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/How_To_Contribute#Contributor_License_Agreement .. _`upload an SSH key`: https://review.openstack.org/#/settings/ssh-keys .. _`Gerrit Workflow's account setup`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow#Account_Setup Set up your environment ------------------------ Clone the Zaqar repository: $ git clone git://git.openstack.org/openstack/zaqar.git For more information on how to set up the Zaqar development environment see :doc:`development-environment`. Before starting to code, you will have to do some initial configurations to connect your local repository with Gerrit. You will only need to do this your first time setting up the development environment. Before you start work, make sure you have git-review installed on your system. $ pip install git-review Git-review checks that you can log in to Gerrit with your SSH key. It assumes that your Gerrit/Launchpad user name is the same as the current running user. You can configure your Gerrit username so you don't have to keep re-entering your username: $ git config --global gitreview.username yourgerritusername You can view your Gerrit user name in the `settings page`_. Ask git-review to configure the project and install the gerrit change-id commit hook: $ cd zaqar $ git review -s If you get the error "We don't know where your Gerrit is", you will need to add a new git remote. The URL should be in the error message. Copy that and create the new remote. It looks something like: $ git remote add gerrit ssh://<username>@review.openstack.org:29418/openstack/zaqar.git In the project directory, you have a .git hidden directory and a .gitreview hidden file. You can see them with: $ ls -la .. _`settings page`: https://review.openstack.org/#/settings/ Making a Patch -------------- Pick or report a bug #################### You can start tacking some bugs from the `bugs list in Launchpad`_. If you find a bug you want to work on, assign yourself. Make sure to read the bug report. If you need more information, ask the reporter to provide more details through a comment on launchpad or through IRC or email. If you find a bug and it's not in the bugs list in Launchpad, report it and ask for another developer to confirm it. When it's confirmed, you can start working on it. Some things you might want to include when filling out a bug report: * The release, or milestone, or commit ID corresponding to the software that you are running * The operating system and version where you've identified the bug * Steps to reproduce the bug, including what went wrong * Description of the expected results instead of what you saw * Portions of your log files so that you include only relevant excerpts In the bug comments, you can contribute instructions on how to fix a given bug, and set it to Triaged. You can read more about `launchpad bugs`_ in the wiki. .. _`bugs list in Launchpad`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/marconi .. _`launchpad bugs`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Bugs Workflow ######### Make sure your repo is up to date: $ git remote update $ git checkout master $ git pull --ff-only origin master Create a topic branch: $ git checkout -b TOPIC-BRANCH If you are working on a blueprint, name your topic branch bp/BLUEPRINT where BLUEPRINT is the name of a blueprint in launchpad (for example, "bp/authentication"). The general convention when working on bugs is to name the branch bug/BUG-NUMBER (for example, "bug/1234567"). Read more about the `Gerrit workflow`_. .. _`Gerrit workflow`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow Design principles ################# Marconi lives by the following design principles: * `DRY`_ * `YAGNI`_ * `KISS`_ .. _`DRY`: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself .. _`YAGNI`: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YAGNI .. _`KISS`: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KISS_principle Try to stick to them when working on your patch. Test your code ############## It is important to test your code and follow code style guidelines. See :doc:`running_tests` for details. Submitting a Patch ------------------ Once you finished coding your fix, add and commit your final changes. Your commit message should: * Provide a brief description of the change in the first line. * Insert a single blank line after the first line. * Provide a detailed description of the change in the following lines, breaking paragraphs where needed. * The first line should be limited to 50 characters and should not end with a period. * Subsequent lines should be wrapped at 72 characters. * Put the 'Change-id', 'Closes-Bug #NNNNN' and 'blueprint NNNNNNNNNNN' lines at the very end. Read more about `making a good commit message`_. To submit it for review use: $ git review You will see the URL of your patch once it is successfully sent. You can also see your reviews in "My Changes" in `Gerrit`_. The first thing to watch for is a +1 in the "Verified" column next to your patch in the server and/or client list of pending patches. If the "Jenkins" user gives you a -1, you'll need to check the log it posts to find out what gate test failed, update your patch, and resubmit. You can set your patch as a "work in progress" if your patch is not ready to be merged, but you would still like some feedback from other developers. To do this leave a review on your patch setting "Workflow" to -1. Once the gate has verified your patch, other Zaqar devs will take a look and submit their comments. When you get two or more +2's from core reviewers, the patch will be approved and merged. Don't be discouraged if a reviewer submits their comments with a "-1"; they just want to make sure you and other reviewers notice the submitted question or suggestion. To reply to feedback save all your comments as draft, then click on the review button. When replying to feedback, you as the patch author will typically just use the score of "0". The only exception is when you discover a blocking issue and you don't want your patch to accidentally get merged while you are discussing the patch with the team; in that case, you can vote on your own patch with a "-2", while you decide whether to keep, refactor, or withdraw the patch. .. _`making a good commit message`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages .. _`Gerrit`: https://review.openstack.org/

commit_message:
Remove docutils-pin

This was added to work around bug 1091333.  A new sphinx has been
released and so this is no longer necessary.

The docutils-pin has been removed from all projects listed
in projects.txt.
The patches removing the pin have used the IDs
I99ae8f8be1aa19508af05f2f72dea89537478f2f and
I6ea61a3cc441dd1ca2ced7e2fd837a55b917f76d .

There are a some projects not listed in projects.txt that still have the
docutils-pin, patches for these are under review.

Change-Id: Ic3208d181c0bdb4521ee2b062d8414ef7ac33230
Co-Authored-By: James E. Blair <jeblair@hp.com>

ML2: Make get_device_details report mac address as well

This will be used by ofagent to route packets to local VMs.

Partially-implements: blueprint ofagent-merge-bridges

commit_message:
Remove unneeded device_owner field from l2pop tuple

The DVR development added this device_owner to the middle of this
tuple during early development because it was thought to be needed.
Over the course of development, it was found to be unnecessary and
much of the code that read it from this value was removed or
obsoleted.  That job went unfinished and so this commit completes it.
This essentially restores the code to what it was before and fixes the
regression that was caused.

Change-Id: Ia901f925883b53e9880dd25688e16e0ffe402bf4
Partial-bug: #1352801

commit_message:
Remove install guide dashboard session section

After another bug report about configuring dashboard sessions
using the installation guide, I decided to update the Icehouse
version to reference the Cloud Administrator Guide similar to the
Juno version.

Change-Id: I0d20720e527504b5c9a30d113e5591b486d9cb5b
Closes-Bug: #1354896

The Windows installer displays " "a list of drivers to install. commit_message:
peer_id attribute can be IPv4/IPv6 address

as per design now.
in notes mentioned as it can be IPv4/IPv6 address,
e-mail address, key id, or FQDN.

Change-Id: I54bd1b30cf9479bed35147ca310b0894dadc2a90
Closes-Bug: 1364221
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/87/118287/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: msgid "Peer router identity for authentication. Can be IPv4/IPv6 address or FQDN."
deleted_lines: msgid "Peer router identity for authentication. Can be IPv4/IPv6 address, e-mail address, key id, or FQDN."

subject: Use openstack.common.lockutils module for locks in tox functional tests.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-20 06:15:09.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0e2af67d3556a848ff34482c3f3448f9f5b8ec21', 'message': 'Use openstack.common.lockutils module for locks in tox functional tests.

Tox test has been switched to use openstack.common.lockutils module
for interprocess locks. However neutron tox functional tests was
left behind probably because locking is not required by the existing
functional test cases. This change makes neutron tox functional tests
adopt openstack.common.lockutils for locking.

Closes-Bug: 1332380
Change-Id: I4d6076e5f7586a11ea5381f18774d4bab57b0081
'}]
commit_message:
Use openstack.common.lockutils module for locks in tox functional tests.

Tox test has been switched to use openstack.common.lockutils module
for interprocess locks. However neutron tox functional tests was
left behind probably because locking is not required by the existing
functional test cases. This change makes neutron tox functional tests
adopt openstack.common.lockutils for locking.

Closes-Bug: 1332380
Change-Id: I4d6076e5f7586a11ea5381f18774d4bab57b0081
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/24/101424/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python -m neutron.openstack.common.lockutils python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args='{posargs}'

commit_message:
Proper validation for inserting firewall rule

Say rule r2 is associated with policy p2. If user tries to insert rule r1
into a policy p1 before/after r2, error should be thrown saying that rule
r2 is not associated with policy p1.

Change-Id: Ifa415acc9533b7a323f966ee42d476460e68c9d3
Closes-bug: 1330898

added_lines: if ref_fwr_db.firewall_policy_id != id: raise firewall.FirewallRuleNotAssociatedWithPolicy( firewall_rule_id=ref_fwr_db['id'], firewall_policy_id=id)

commit_message:
Adding new methods to DB API v2 (load_xxx and create_or_update_xxx)

* Methods load_xxx() which can return None unlike get_xxx()
* Methods create_or_update_xxx()
* Unit tests for new methods
* Refactoring DB tests

Change-Id: Ieb1985d0a9cf70b41a166a4f97251dd5c108576c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/72/116872/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Made provision for glance service to use Launcher
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-27 11:07:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/441d894f65456e5e36c84df702a892237a787c10', 'message': "Made provision for glance service to use Launcher

After sending SIGHUP signal to glance-service parent process,
it will call SIGHUP callback handler and then throws OSError.
The OSError is thrown because os.wait system call was
interrupted due to SIGHUP callback handler. As a result of
this parent process closes the server socket.
All child processes also gets terminated without completing
existing api requests because the server socket is already
closed and the service doesn't restart.

Added service module, launcher and common service module with
its dependencies from oslo-incubator in glance service.

After modifying the implemenatation, glance-service is able to
restart on sending SIGHUP signal to parent process and also
completing existing api requests.

Made provision to pass default hub to eventlet.hubs.use_hub()
in oslo-incubator common service famework. Defined new configuration
parameter 'eventlet_hub' with default value as 'poll' in glance.cmd.api
and glance.cmd.registry  and leveraged same to service framework of
oslo-incubator.

Change-Id: I8fe08d2ee3fb2f29e7cffe04514866f8e9bb1933
blueprint:use-common-service-framework

commit_message:
Made provision for glance service to use Launcher

After sending SIGHUP signal to glance-service parent process,
it will call SIGHUP callback handler and then throws OSError.
The OSError is thrown because os.wait system call was
interrupted due to SIGHUP callback handler. As a result of
this parent process closes the server socket.
All child processes also gets terminated without completing
existing api requests because the server socket is already
closed and the service doesn't restart.

Added service module, launcher and common service module with
its dependencies from oslo-incubator in glance service.

After modifying the implemenatation, glance-service is able to
restart on sending SIGHUP signal to parent process and also
completing existing api requests.

Made provision to pass default hub to eventlet.hubs.use_hub()
in oslo-incubator common service framework. Defined new configuration
parameter 'eventlet_hub' with default value as 'poll' in glance.cmd.api
and glance.cmd.registry  and leveraged same to service framework of
oslo-incubator.

Change-Id: I8fe08d2ee3fb2f29e7cffe04514866f8e9bb1933
blueprint:use-common-service-framework

Create a workflow(scope=private) as under one project # then make sure it's NOT visible for other projects. created1 = db_api.create_workflow(WORKFLOWS[1]) fetched = db_api.get_workflows() self.assertEqual(1, len(fetched)) self.assertEqual(created1, fetched[0]) # Create a new user. ctx = auth_context.MistralContext( user_id='9-0-44-5', project_id='99-88-33', user_name='test-user', project_name='test-another', is_admin=False ) auth_context.set_ctx(ctx) fetched = db_api.get_workflows() self.assertEqual(0, len(fetched)) def test_workflow_public(self): # Create a workflow(scope=public) as under one project # then make sure it's visible for other projects. created0 = db_api.create_workflow(WORKFLOWS[0]) fetched = db_api.get_workflows() self.assertEqual(1, len(fetched)) self.assertEqual(created0, fetched[0]) # Assert that the project_id stored is actually the context's # project_id not the one given. self.assertEqual(created0['project_id'], auth_context.ctx().project_id) self.assertNotEqual( WORKFLOWS[0]['project_id'], auth_context.ctx().project_id ) # Create a new user. ctx = auth_context.MistralContext( user_id='9-0-44-5', project_id='99-88-33', user_name='test-user', project_name='test-another', is_admin=False ) auth_context.set_ctx(ctx) fetched = db_api.get_workflows() self.assertEqual(1, len(fetched)) self.assertEqual(created0, fetched[0]) self.assertEqual('public', created0['scope']) def test_workflow_repr(self): s = db_api.create_workflow(WORKFLOWS[0]).__repr__() self.assertIn('Workflow ', s) self.assertIn("'name': 'my_wf1'", s)

subject: Fix "mutable" object as default value

This patch fix the coding issue where "mutable" objects like list, dict
are being used as default value of param.

Currently there might be no scenario where "mutable" object as default value
create issue (as they maintain the state across function call) but in future
function can be called which can create the issue.

Those needs to be replace by taking default value as 'None' and have
if else condition accordingly in function def.

Change-Id: I251b316ef6d37f4b95c5e8d73a20a39005c22870
Closes-Bug: #1330322
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-06-16 09:33:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/559efb39f445e794bb601a56498eb27f7806cdd4', 'message': 'Fix "mutbale" object as default value

are being used as default value of param.

Current functions with mutable object as default value can create issues
if they will be called in more random order.
For example - first call with non default value and then with default
value. In this case original default will be overridden by the first
function call (as mutable object keep their state among function calls).

Such param's default value needs to be replace by 'None' and have
if else condition accordingly in function def.

commit_message:
Fix "mutable" object as default value

This patch fix the coding issue where "mutable" objects like list, dict
are being used as default value of param.

Current functions with mutable object as default value can create issues
if they will be called in more random order.
For example - first call with non default value and then with default
value. In this case original default will be overridden by the first
function call (as mutable object keep their state among function calls).

This commit also add the hacking check for the same and its
corresponding test.

Closes-Bug: #1330322

Change-Id: I251b316ef6d37f4b95c5e8d73a20a39005c22870

commit_message:
Increase cinder volumes hard disk size

Increases cinder volumes hard disk size to 4GB. 2GB was not sufficient
for creating multiple volumes at once.

Change-Id: Iae9a8a4f71a297f0bbf017b80011cb9cc6d517cb

commit_message:
Updates cinder to support additional image types

Only raw images can be converted to bootable volumes by cinder. For
converting additional image types, cinder needs 'qemu-img' which is
installed via 'qemu-utils' package. This patch adds the required
package to the cinder controller node.

Change-Id: I296649827165989381ac7ce623e7babd62f7063a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/46/118446/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo apt-get install -y cinder-api cinder-scheduler qemu-utils # Note: The package 'qemu-utils' is required for 'qemu-img' which allows cinder # to convert additional image types to bootable volumes. By default only # raw images can be converted.
